hedline.hl1: Giuliani Eases Transfer of Funds to Lazio

abstract.p: Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani develops plan to ease transfer of contributions to his now-defunct United States Senate campaign to Republican candidate, Representative Rick A Lazio; cashier's checks will be sent to contributors with letter urging them to endorse check over to Lazio campaign; stamped envelope addressed to Lazio's campaign headquarters will also be included (S)

block.p: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has come up with a plan that his aides say will make it easier for the contributors to his now-defunct campaign for the United States Senate to give their money to the new Republican candidate, Representative Rick A. Lazio.

Mr. Giuliani's campaign will send cashier's checks to the contributors, along with a letter from the mayor urging them to endorse the checks over to Mr. Lazio's campaign. A stamped envelope addressed to Mr. Lazio's campaign headquarters will be included in the mailing, to make things even easier.

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has come up with a plan that his aides say will make it easier for the contributors to his now-defunct campaign for the United States Senate to give their money to the new Republican candidate, Representative Rick A. Lazio.

Mr. Giuliani's campaign will send cashier's checks to the contributors, along with a letter from the mayor urging them to endorse the checks over to Mr. Lazio's campaign. A stamped envelope addressed to Mr. Lazio's campaign headquarters will be included in the mailing, to make things even easier.

The contributions in question amount to just under $3 million. Bruce J. Teitelbaum, who managed Mr. Giuliani's campaign, said that no decision had been made about how Mr. Giuliani would dispose of another $3 million or so, out of $20 million raised, that will remain in the campaign fund.
Dan McLagan, a spokesman for Mr. Lazio, said, ''They're doing everything they can to help, and we're very appreciative.''
